1. I first analyzed the correlation between the population statistics (no-vehicle, low-income, age-18-24 and age-25-64). The correlation coefficient here is not impressive,  but the comparison may show something.

population-low-income vs. avg-load   0.371
houseunits-no-vehicle   0.341
population-density   0.133
population  0.339
population-age-18-24   0.361
population-age-25-64    0.335

So, it is most correlated with population with low income, in comparison to other factors. Also, population between age 18-24 is only second to it. 

2. Then I aggregate the statistics over the bus route to get the correlation coefficient by routes:

population-low-income vs. avg-load   0.628
houseunits-no-vehicle   0.385
population-density 0.853
population  0.766
population-age-18-24   0.727
population-age-25-64    0.719

Here it is a little surprising that population density is the most significant factor while in 1 it is least correlated. That should be just a trick of statistics that "bus route" is a more generalized unit than "bus stop", while "population density" is more generalized too. 

Then, we don't see an age group which shows more correlation than overall population. So, people with all ages take the bus as a result of the generalization. However, one useful thing may be people-low-income is much more correlated than houseunits-with-no-vehicle, while no-vehicle may be intuitively a better factor. 

3. The research then moves to the next question: we want to see whether bus routes differ from others. Do we have some bus routes that match the population better/less than others? 

So, to test this, I take one bus route out and calculate the correlation coefficient of all other routes. To get more sensitivity, I used the average statistics (not the aggregation in 2) so the correlation coefficient falls to a low level again. But the point here is: the variance matters. 

I still use the factors as above (the min correlation means this bus route is more correlated; the max correlation means the bus route is like outlier):

population-low-income vs. avg-load 
route:corr_coef

2:0.233047035948

so, 908 and 39 seem to appear multiple times here.

4.  just ran the comparison over bus stops (unlike bus routes in the last email). 

So, these two always show there over almost all the factors:

"most correlated" stop:  id: 6522  name : STOCKTON ST&SACRAMENTO ST W-
"most outlier" stop: id: 3161  name: 4TH ST&MARKET ST S-FS/BB - EOL
